datafield.subfield: On the dynamical and topological nature of the chiral magnetic effect in Weyl semimetals

Quantum field theory predicts Weyl semimetals to possess a peculiar response of the longitudinal current density to the application of a DC magnetic field. Such a response function has been shown to be at odds with a general result showing the vanishing of the bulk current in an equilibrium system on any real material with a lattice in an external magnetic field. Here we resolve this apparent contradiction by introducing a source of equilibriation namely weak bulk disorder. By calculating the response function of a disordered Weyl semimetal away from the Weyl point, we show analytically and numerically that the chiral magnetic response vanishes in the dc limit, but crosses over to the predicted value from field theory at frequencies exceeding the scattering rate. Addtionally, we provide an example of a system where the chiral magnetic effect could appear even in the absence of a Weyl point. The simplest Fermi surface, which has a Berry curvature and breaks inversion symmetry is sufficient to produce a small chiral magnetic effect, without any need for a topological Berry flux.
